member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.EventResponseArgs
member.summary: Configures how to simulate events that interrupt the application flow on the device, such as an incoming call or SMS.
member.remarks: These simulated events can help you test that your application responds properly to the event itself and to state transitions. For example, you may want to verify that when an incoming SMS is received, your application is sent to the background for several seconds, and, when it returns to the foreground, the application is in an active state, ready to continue.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.EventResponseArgs.TimeInBackground
member.summary: The time (in seconds) that the application remains in the background while the event is being handled. Default = 10

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.EventResponseArgs.RespondToEvent
member.summary: Indicates whether there is a response to the simulated event. Default = false

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.EventResponseArgs.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the EventResponseArgs class with default arguments (TimeInBackground = 10 seconds; RespondToEvent = false).

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.IDropDown
member.summary: A drop-down object in a mobile application.

members.member:
Selects the specified item or items by index. Multiple indexes are supported only for iOS.
CODE SAMPLE NEEDED For an iOS picker wheel, you can pass an index for each wheel.
For an Android drop-down, pass only one index. CODE SAMPLE NEEDED The 0-based indexes of the items to select.

Selects the specified items by name from the corresponding picker wheel's list of values. (iOS only)
CODE SAMPLE NEEDED The names of the items to select in each wheel.

Selects the specified item in the specified picker wheel by index. (iOS only)
QUESTION: Do we want to use the term component or picker or wheel? Yeal RND to change to wheel The 0-based index of the picker wheel in which to select the specified item. The 0-based index of the item to select in the specified picker wheel.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.PinchArgs.Velocity
member.summary: The speed at which to perform the pinch operation.
member.remarks: This number specifies the scale factor per second, meaning the ratio between the touch point distance at one second, and the touch point distance one second later. For example, if performing a pinch from 6 cm to 3 cm (0.5 scale) takes 2 seconds, then the velocity is 0.25.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.UiObjectBaseDescription.Vri
member.summary: Distinguishes this object from other objects with otherwise identical descriptions, based on this object's visual relationship to another object in the application.
member.remarks: For example if you have 10 identical buttons with the text label "Buy" and no other real property to distinguish between them, you can use VRI to indicate that this test object represents the "Buy" button that is located to the right of the image of a specific product. The Vri property value is a object that defines the test object you are relating to, and where that related object is located on the screen relative to the object to identify. For more details, see the UFT Developer Help Center.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.Device.UploadMedia(System.Uri,System.String)
member.summary: Upload a media file to the device for camera or video simulation. The files are deleted when the device is released. Supported formats: JPG, GIF, PNG, BMP, TIF (iOS only), MP4, 3GP (Android only), MKV (Android only), MOV (iOS only), M4V (iOS only).
member.param: The URL, including the extention, of the media file (image or video).
The unique ID of the uploaded media. The ID is used to start the simulation using Application.StartCameraSimulationMode.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.Device.UploadMedia(System.Uri,System.String,HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.MediaUploadOptions)
member.summary: Upload a media file to the device for camera or video simulation, with the option to save the file to the Pictures folder. The files are deleted when the device is released. Supported formats: JPG, GIF, PNG, BMP, TIF (iOS only), MP4, 3GP (Android only), MKV (Android only), MOV (iOS only), M4V (iOS only).
member.param: The URL, including the extention, of the media file (image or video).
The unique ID of the uploaded media. The ID is used to start the simulation using Application.StartCameraSimulationMode.
The option to save the file to the Pictures folder. The default is False.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.MobileLab.LockDeviceByName(System.String)
member.summary: Obtains a device from the UFT Mobile lab by device name and locks it, so that only the current UFT Developer test can perform actions on it.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.MobileLab.LockDeviceByInfo(HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.IDeviceInfo)
member.summary: Obtains a device from the UFT Mobile lab by device information and locks it, so that only the current UFT Developer test can perform actions on it.
member.remarks: If the lock operation fails, the LockDeviceByInfo method throws an exception.
member.param: An interface () containing information about the device to lock.
member.returns: The locked device.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.MobileLab.TryLockDeviceByInfo(HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.IDeviceInfo,HP.LFT.SDK.Mobile.IDevice@)
member.summary: Checks whether a device is available in the UFT Mobile lab and, if so, locks it so that only the current UFT Developer test can perform actions on it.
member.remarks: If this method fails, the test continues without an exception.
member.param: An interface () containing information about the device to lock.
If the method returns True, this parameter contains the locked IDevice. If the method returns False, the parameter contains a null value.
member.returns: True if the locking operation succeeded, otherwise false.

members.member:
Opens a remote access window in UFT Mobile with the specified application loaded on the specified device. If the specified device is already open in a remote access window, the application launches according to the .
QUESTION: Should we say when this should be used? How does this fit into running a test silently? The device is locked as long as the remote access window is open. The ID of device to open in the remote access window. The ID of the application to launch on the specified device. The identifier of the application to launch on the specified device. The version of the application. The counter of the application. for installing and opening the specified application. Indicates whether the application is packaged or not.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.PowerBuilder.ITable.GetTableProperty(System.String)
member.summary: GetTableProperty uses the PowerBuilder Describe method to return the value of one property of a DataWindow object and controls within the DataWindow object. Each column and graphic control in the DataWindow has a set of properties. You specify one property as a string, and GetTableProperty returns the values of the property.
member.param: Property name. Possible values: http://infocenter.sybase.com/help/topic/com.sybase.infocenter.dc37783.1252/html/dwref/CCJBHCCF.htm
member.returns: A string that includes the value of property.Null if the specified property has no value.
member.example: How to use PowerBuilder Describe method: http://infocenter.sybase.com/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.sybase.infocenter.dc37783.1252/html/dwref/BFCEADCH.htm
member.remarks: The GetTableProperty throws GeneralReplayException for invalid items.
The GetTableProperty returns null for property that have no value.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.PowerBuilder.ITable.EvaluateExpression(System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: EvaluateExpression uses the PowerBuilder Describe methodto evaluate one expressioninvolving values of a particular row and column.
member.param: The expression you want to evaluate.In this expression, include a specification of the relevant column.
The number of the row for which you want to evaluate the expression.
member.returns: The result of evaluating the expression. In the example below, EvaluateExpression returns a string with the value of 1 or 0 depending on the value of the field1 column and row 2.
member.example: How to usePowerBuilder Describe method to evaluate an expression: http://infocenter.sybase.com/help/index.jsp?topic=/com.sybase.infocenter.dc37783.1252/html/dwref/BFCEADCH.htm
member.remarks: The EvaluateExpression throws GeneralReplayException for an invalid expression.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.IEditField.SetSecure(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the encoded value of this edit box.

Generate the encoded value using the Password Encoder utility, available from the UFT Developer > Tools menu in your IDE or from the Windows Start menu.
Note: The SetSecure method enables you to hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, but it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.IGuiSession.Close
member.summary: Closes the SAP GUI for Windows session without displaying a warning message.
member.remarks: You can invoke this method at the end of an action or test iteration to close sessions that were opened during the test run. This ensures that each iteration begins with the same number of open SAP Gui for Windows sessions.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory
member.summary: A class for creating an instance.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(System.String)
member.summary: Launches the SAP Gui session on the given server description.
member.param: The server to which you want to log on. The string is case-sensitive and must be identical to the one displayed in the SAP Logon dialog box.
member.returns: The launched session

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a connection to the specified SAP server according to its IP address
member.param: The connection IP for the SAP server to which you want to open a connection.
The server system number
member.returns: The launched session
member.exception: In case server IP is null.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Launches the SAP Gui session and perform the log-in according to the specified user credentials on the specified server description.
member.remarks:
Generate the password encoded value using the Password Encoder utility (CryptonApp.exe), available from the UFT Developer menu in your IDE, or from the UFT Developer installation\bin folder.
Note: While the encrypted value hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.
member.param: The server to which you want to log on. The string is case-sensitive and must be identical to the one displayed in the SAP Logon dialog box.
The SAP client you want to use.
The username with which you want to log on to the SAP Server.
The encrypted value of the password for the specified username.
The 2-letter code for the language you want to use.
member.returns: The launched session

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(System.Net.IPAddress,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Launches the SAP Gui session and perform the log-in according to the specified user credentials on the specified server ip.
member.remarks:
Generate the password encoded value using the Password Encoder utility (CryptonApp.exe), available from the UFT Developer menu in your IDE, or from the UFT Developer installation\bin folder.
Note: While the encrypted value hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.
member.param: The connection IP for the SAP server to which you want to open a connection.
The SAP client you want to use.
The username with which you want to log on to the SAP Server.
The encrypted value of the password for the specified username.
The 2-letter code for the language you want to use.
member.returns: The launched session

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.SessionLaunchInfo,HP.LFT.SDK.IDesktopEnvironment)
member.summary: Launches the SAP GUI session and logs on to the server using the user credentials and details specified in the launchInfo parameter. Use this overload when working with a UFT Developer grid.
member.param: The session launch information.
The environment on which to launch the GUI session, obtained using the method.
member.returns: The launched session.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Launch(HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.SessionLaunchInfo)
member.summary: Launches the SAP GUI session and logs on to the server using the user credentials and details specified in the launchInfo parameter.
member.param: The session launch information.
member.returns: The launched session.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.Attach(HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionDescription)
member.summary: Returns a new instance that is attached to a session that was not opened by UFT Developer (for example, a session that was opened manually or by the AUT).
member.remarks:
is used only when attaching to the session so transient properties like can be used.
UFT Developer recognizes SAP GUI Session and tabs that it opens (for example, via ). If a GUI Session is opened outside of the UFT Developer context, you need to use the method to acquire the GUI session.
member.param: for filtering the open sessions.
member.returns: for the launched session if a single matching sessions was found.
member.exception: No open sessions matches the description.
More than one session matches the description.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionFactory.GetAllOpenSessions(HP.LFT.SDK.SAP.GUI.GuiSessionDescription)
member.summary: Returns the open sessions that match the description.
member.param: A containing the set of properties and values that should be common to all returned sessions.
member.returns: A collection of objects that are open and match the description.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole
member.summary: Describe the roles of various UI objects in an application.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.TitleBar
member.summary: The object represents a title or caption bar for a window.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.MenuBar
member.summary: The object represents the menu bar (positioned beneath the title bar of a window) from which users select menus.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ScrollBar
member.summary: The object represents a vertical or horizontal scroll bar, which is part of the client area or is used in a control.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Grip
member.summary: The object represents a special mouse pointer that allows a user to manipulate user interface elements such as windows. One example of this involves resizing a window by dragging its lower-right corner.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Sound
member.summary: The object represents a system sound, which is associated with various system events.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Cursor
member.summary: The object represents the system's mouse pointer.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Caret
member.summary: The object represents the system's caret.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Alert
member.summary: The object represents an alert or a condition that a user should be notified about. This role is used only for objects that embody an alert but are not associated with another user interface element, such as a message box, graphic, text, or sound.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Window
member.summary: The object represents the window frame, which contains child objects such as a title bar, client, and other objects of a window.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Client
member.summary: The object represents a window's client area. Microsoft Active Accessibility uses this role as a default if there is a question about the role of a UI element.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.MenuPopup
member.summary: The object represents a menu: a list of options, each with a specific action. All menu types must have a role, including the drop-down menus which are displayed when selected from a menu bar; and shortcut menus, which are displayed by clicking the right mouse button.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.MenuItem
member.summary: The object represents a menu item: an menu entry that the user can choose to carry out a command, select an option, or display another menu. Functionally, a menu item is equivalent to a push button, a radio button, a check box, or a menu.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ToolTip
member.summary: The object represents a tooltip that provides helpful hints.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Application
member.summary: The object represents a main window for an application.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Document
member.summary: The object represents a document window. A document window is always contained within an application window. This role applies only to MDI windows and refers to the object that contains the MDI title bar.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Pane
member.summary: The object represents a pane within a frame or a document window. Users can navigate between panes and within the contents of the current pane, but cannot navigate between items in different panes. Thus, panes represent a grouping level that is lower than frames or document windows, but higher than individual controls. The user navigates between panes by pressing TAB, F6, or CTRL+TAB, depending on the context.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Chart
member.summary: The object represents a graphical image used to chart data.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Dialog
member.summary: The object represents a dialog box or message box.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Border
member.summary: The object represents a window border. The entire border is represented by a single object rather than by separate objects for each side.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Grouping
member.summary: The object logically groups other objects. There is not always a parent-child relationship between the grouping object and the objects it contains.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Separator
member.summary: The object is used to visually divide a space into two regions. Examples of separator objects include a separator menu item, and a bar that divides split panes within a window.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ToolBar
member.summary: The object represents a toolbar, which is a grouping of controls that provides easy access to frequently used features.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.StatusBar
member.summary: The object represents a status bar, which is an area at the bottom of a window and which displays information about the current operation, state of the application, or selected object. The status bar has multiple fields, which display different kinds of information.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Table
member.summary: The object represents a table that contains rows and columns of cells, and, optionally, row headers and column headers.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ColumnHeader
member.summary: The object represents a column header, providing a visual label for a column in a table.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.RowHeader
member.summary: The object represents a row header, which provides a visual label for a table row.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Column
member.summary: The object represents a column of cells within a table.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Row
member.summary: The object represents a row of cells within a table.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Cell
member.summary: The object represents a cell within a table.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Link
member.summary: The object represents a link to something else. This object might look like text or a graphic, but it acts like a button.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.HelpBalloon
member.summary: The object displays a help topic in the form of a tooltip or help balloon.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Character
member.summary: The object represents a cartoon-like graphic object, such as Microsoft Office Assistant, which is displayed to provide help to users of an application.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.List
member.summary: The object represents a list box, allowing the user to select one or more items.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ListItem
member.summary: The object represents an item in a list box or in the list portion of a combo box, drop-down list box, or drop-down combo box.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Outline
member.summary: The object represents an outline or a tree structure, such as a tree view control, that displays a hierarchical list and allows the user to expand and collapse branches.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.OutlineItem
member.summary: The object represents an item that navigates like an outline item. The UP and DOWN ARROW keys are used to navigate through the outline. However, instead of expanding and collapsing when the LEFT and RIGHT ARROW key is pressed, these menus expand or collapse when the SPACEBAR or ENTER key is pressed and the item has focus.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.PageTab
member.summary: The object represents a page tab. The only child of a page tab control is a ROLE_SYSTEM_GROUPING object that has the contents of the associated page.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.PropertyPage
member.summary: The object represents a property sheet.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Indicator
member.summary: The object represents an indicator, such as a pointer graphic, that points to the current item.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Graphic
member.summary: The object represents a picture.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.StaticText
member.summary: The object represents read-only text, such as labels for other controls or instructions in a dialog box. Static text cannot be modified or selected.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Text
member.summary: The object represents selectable text that allows edits or is designated as read-only.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.PushButton
member.summary: The object represents a push-button control.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.CheckButton
member.summary: The object represents a check box control: an option that is selected or cleared independently of other options.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.RadioButton
member.summary: The object represents an option button (formerly, a radio button). It is one of a group of mutually exclusive options. All objects that share the same parent and that have this attribute are assumed to be part of a single mutually exclusive group. To divide these objects into separate groups, use ROLE_SYSTEM_GROUPING objects.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ComboBox
member.summary: The object represents a combo box: an edit control with an associated list box that provides a set of predefined choices.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.DropList
member.summary: The object represents the calendar control, SysDateTimePick32. The Microsoft Active Accessibility runtime component uses this role to indicate that either a date or a calendar control has been found.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ProgressBar
member.summary: The object represents a progress bar, which dynamically shows how much of an operation in progress has completed. This control takes no user input.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Dial
member.summary: The object represents a dial or knob.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.HotKeyField
member.summary: The object represents a keyboard shortcut field that allows the user to enter a combination or sequence of keystrokes.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Slider
member.summary: The object represents a slider, which allows the user to adjust a setting in particular increments between minimum and maximum values.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.SpinButton
member.summary: The object represents a spin box, which is a control that allows the user to increment or decrement the value displayed in a separate "buddy" control that is associated with the spin box.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Diagram
member.summary: The object represents a graphical image that is used to diagram data.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Animation
member.summary: The object represents an animation control whose content changes over time, such as a control that displays a series of bitmap frames. Animation controls are displayed when files are copied or when some other time-consuming task is performed.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Equation
member.summary: The object represents a mathematical equation.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ButtonDropDown
member.summary: The object represents a button that expands a list of items.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ButtonMenu
member.summary: The object represents a button that expands a menu.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.ButtonDropDownGrid
member.summary: The object represents a button that expands a grid.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.WhiteSpace
member.summary: The object represents blank space between other objects.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.PageTabList
member.summary: The object represents a container of page tab controls.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.Clock
member.summary: The object represents a control that displays time.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.SplitButton
member.summary: The object represents a button on a toolbar that has a drop-down list icon that is directly adjacent to the button.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.IpAddress
member.summary: The object represents an edit control that is designed for an IP address. The edit control is divided into sections, each for a specific part of the IP address.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleRole.OutlineButton
member.summary: The object represents an item that navigates like an outline item. The UP and DOWN ARROW keys are used to navigate through the outline. However, instead of expanding and collapsing when the LEFT and RIGHT ARROW key is pressed, these menus expand or collapse when the SPACEBAR or ENTER key is pressed and the item has focus.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState
member.summary: Describe the state of objects in an application UI.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Unavailable
member.summary: The object is unavailable.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Selected
member.summary: The object is selected.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Focused
member.summary: The object has the keyboard focus. Do not confuse object focus with object selection. For more information, see Selection and Focus Properties and Methods. For objects with this object state, send the EVENT_OBJECT_SHOW or EVENT_OBJECT_HIDE WinEvents to notify client applications about state changes. Do not use EVENT_OBJECT_STATECHANGE.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Pressed
member.summary: The object is pressed.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Checked
member.summary: The object's check box is selected.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Mixed
member.summary: Indicates that the state of a three-state check box or toolbar button is not determined. The check box is neither selected nor cleared and is therefore in the third or mixed state.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.ReadOnly
member.summary: The object is designated read-only.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.HotTracked
member.summary: The object is hot-tracked by the mouse, which means that the object's appearance has changed to indicate that the mouse pointer is located over it.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Default
member.summary: This state represents the default button in a window.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Expanded
member.summary: The object's children that have the role are displayed.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Collapsed
member.summary: The object's children that have the role are hidden.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Busy
member.summary: The control cannot accept input at this time.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Floating
member.summary: The object is not clipped to the boundary of its parent object, and it does not move automatically when the parent moves.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Marqueed
member.summary: Indicates scrolling or moving text or graphics.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Animated
member.summary: The object's appearance changes rapidly or constantly. Graphics that are animated occasionally are described as with the State property set to . This state is used to indicate that the object's location is changing.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Invisible
member.summary: The object is programmatically hidden. For example, menu itmes are programmatically hidden until a user activates the menu. Because objects with this state are not available to users, client applications must not communicate information about the object to users. However, if client applications find an object with this state, they should check whether is also set. If this second state is defined, clients can communicate the information about the object to users. For example, a list box can have both and set. In this case, the client application can communicate all items in the list to users. If a client application is navigating through an IAccessible tree and encounters a parent object that is invisible, Microsoft Active Accessibility will not expose information about any possible children of the parent as long as the parent is invisible.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.OffScreen
member.summary: The object is clipped or has scrolled out of view, but it is not programmatically hidden. If the user makes the viewport larger, more of the object will be visible on the computer screen.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Sizeable
member.summary: The object can be resized. For example, a user could change the size of a window by dragging it by the border.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Moveable
member.summary: Indicates that the object can be moved. For example, a user can click the object's title bar and drag the object to a new location.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.SelfVoicing
member.summary: The object or child uses text-to-speech (TTS) technology for description purposes. When an object with this state has the focus, a speech-based accessibility aid does not announce information because the object automatically announces it.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Focusable
member.summary: The object is on the active window and is ready to receive keyboard focus.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Selectable
member.summary: The object accepts selection.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Linked
member.summary: Indicates that the object is formatted as a hyperlink. The object's role will usually be .

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Traversed
member.summary: The object is a hyperlink that has been visited (previously clicked) by a user.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.MultiSelectable
member.summary: Indicates that the object accepts multiple selected items; that is, for the IAccessible::accSelect method is valid.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.ExtendSelectable
member.summary: Indicates that an object extends its selection by using in the IAccessible::accSelect method.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.AlertLow
member.summary: Indicates low-priority information that is not important to the user. This state is used, for example, when Word changes the appearance of the TipWizard button on its toolbar to indicate that it has a hint for the user.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.AlertMedium
member.summary: Indicates important information that is not conveyed immediately to the user. For example, when a battery is starting to reach a low level, a level indicator generates a medium-level alert. A blind access tool then generates a sound to let the user know that important information is available, without actually interrupting the user's work. The user could then query the alert information when convenient.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.AlertHigh
member.summary: Indicates important information to be immediately conveyed to the user. For example, when a battery reaches a critically low level, a level indicator generates a high-level alert. As a result, a blind access tool immediately announces this information to the user, and a screen magnification program scrolls the screen so that the battery indicator is in view. This state is also appropriate for any prompt or operation that must be completed before the user can continue.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.AccessibleState.Protected
member.summary: The object is a password-protected edit control.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.Direction
member.summary: Represents pre-defined units of direction for the purposes of navigation within a document.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.Direction.Forward
member.summary: Specifies that the direction is forward.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.Direction.Backward
member.summary: Specifies that the direction is backward.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ScrollAmount
member.summary: Represents pre-defined units of text for the purposes of navigation within a document.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ScrollAmount.SmallIncrement
member.summary: Specifies that scrolling is done in small increments, equivalent to pressing an arrow key or clicking the arrow button on a scrollbar.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ScrollAmount.LargeIncrement
member.summary: Specifies that scrolling is done in large increments, equivalent to a PageDown or clicking on the track of a scrollbar component. equal to the current visible region.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ScrollAmount.SmallDecrement
member.summary: Specifies that scrolling is done in small decrements, equivalent to pressing an arrow key or clicking the arrow button on a scrollbar.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ScrollAmount.LargeDecrement
member.summary: Specifies that scrolling is done in large decrements, equivalent to PageUp or clicking on a blank part of a scrollbar. equal to the current visible window.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions
member.summary: Constant values used to specify how an accessible object becomes selected or takes the focus.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions.TakeFocus
member.summary: Sets the focus to the object and makes it the selection anchor. Used by itself, this flag does not alter the selection. The effect is similar to moving the focus manually by pressing an ARROW key while holding down the CTRL key in Windows Explorer or in any multiple-selection list box.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions.TakeSelection
member.summary: Selects the object and removes the selection from all other objects in the container. Unless it is combined with , this flag does not change the focus or the selection anchor. The | combination is equivalent to single - clicking an item in Windows Explorer.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions.ExtendSelection
member.summary: Alters the selection so that all objects between the selection anchor and this object take on the anchor object's selection state. If the anchor object is not selected, the objects are removed from the selection. If the anchor object is selected, the selection is extended to include this object and all the objects in between. Set the selection state by combining this flag with or . Unless it is combined with , this flag does not change the focus or the selection anchor. The | combination is equivalent to adding an item to a selection manually by holding down the SHIFT key and clicking an unselected object in Windows Explorer. This flag is not combined with .

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions.AddSelection
member.summary: Adds the object to the current selection; possible result is a noncontiguous selection. Unless it is combined with , this flag does not change the focus or the selection anchor. The | combination is equivalent to adding an item to a selection manually by holding down the CTRL key and clicking an unselected object in Windows Explorer. This flag is not combined with or .

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SelectOptions.RemoveSelection
member.summary: Removes the object from the current selection; possible result is a noncontiguous selection. Unless it is combined with , this flag does not change the focus or the selection anchor. The | combination is equivalent to removing an item from a selection manually, by holding down the CTRL key while clicking a selected object in Windows Explorer. This flag is not combined with or .

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SupportedTextSelection
member.summary: Contains values that specify whether a text provider supports selection and, if so, whether it supports a single, continuous selection or multiple, disjointed selections.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SupportedTextSelection.None
member.summary: Does not support text selections.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SupportedTextSelection.Single
member.summary: Supports a single, continuous text selection.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.SupportedTextSelection.Multiple
member.summary: Supports multiple, disjoint text selections.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TableTraversalDirection
member.summary: Contains values that specify whether data in a table should be read primarily by row or by column.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TableTraversalDirection.RowByRow
member.summary: Specifies that data in the table should be read row by row.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TableTraversalDirection.ColumnByColumn
member.summary: Specifies that data in the table should be read column by column.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TableTraversalDirection.Indeterminate
member.summary: Specifies that the best way to present the data is indeterminate.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TextUnit
member.summary: Represents pre-defined units of text for the purposes of navigation within a document.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TextUnit.Line
member.summary: Specifies that the text unit is one line in length.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.TextUnit.Page
member.summary: Specifies that the text unit is one document-specific page in length.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ToggleState
member.summary: Contains values that specify the of a UI Automation element.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ToggleState.Off
member.summary: The UIA Pro element is not selected, checked, marked, or otherwise activated.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ToggleState.On
member.summary: The UIA Pro element is selected, checked, marked, or otherwise activated.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.ToggleState.Indeterminate
member.summary: The UI Automation element is in an indeterminate state. Can be used to indicate whether the user has acted on a control. For example, a check box can appear checked and dimmed, indicating an indeterminate state. Creating an indeterminate state is different from disabling the control. Consequently, a check box in the indeterminate state can still receive the focus. When the user clicks an indeterminate control, the ToggleState cycles to its next value.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState
member.summary: Contains values used by to indicate the window interaction state.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState.Running
member.summary: Indicates that the window is running. This does not guarantee that the window is responding or ready for user interaction.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState.Closing
member.summary: Indicates that the window is closing.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState.ReadyForUserInteraction
member.summary: Indicates that the window is ready for user interaction.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState.BlockedByModalWindow
member.summary: Indicates that the window is blocked by a modal window.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowInteractionState.NotResponding
member.summary: Indicates that the window is not responding.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowVisualState
member.summary: Contains values used by to indicate the window visual state.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowVisualState.Normal
member.summary: Specifies that the window is normal (restored).

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowVisualState.Maximized
member.summary: Specifies that the window is maximized.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.UIAPro.WindowVisualState.Minimized
member.summary: Specifies that the window is minimized.

member.summary: Specifies the expand/collapse state of an automation element.
member.remarks: refers to the visibility of immediate child objects only; it does not refer to the visibility of all descendant objects.

member.summary: No child nodes, controls, or content of the UI Automation element are displayed.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.TreeViewConfiguration
member.summary: A set of XPath values to help the object perform Select, Expand, and Collapse operations in cases where the default implementation cannot find the element needed.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.TreeViewConfiguration.SelectXPath
member.summary: The XPath value used to find the internal tree element used to select a tree node.
member.remarks: Leave this value as a null value if the regular Select operation runs correctly.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.TreeViewConfiguration.ExpandXPath
member.summary: The XPath value used to find the internal tree element used to expand and collapse a tree node.
member.remarks:
Leave this value as a null value if the regular Expand and Collapse methods run correctly.
If the XPath value needed for the Expand operation is different from the XPath value needed for the Collapse operation, use the object.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.TreeViewConfiguration.ForceExpandWithDoubleClick
member.summary: When set to true, the Expand or Collapse operation uses a double click.
member.remarks: The default behavior for the tree is to first try to use a single click. If the node is not expanded with a click it will try to use double click. Setting this property will improve performance when dealing with deep paths.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ExtendedTreeViewConfiguration
member.summary: A set of XPath values to help the object perform Select, Expand, and Collapse operations when the default implementation cannot find the required tree element.
member.remarks: This class extends the by giving the option of a different XPath value for Expand and Collapse operations.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ExtendedTreeViewConfiguration.ExpandXPath
member.summary: The XPath value used to find the internal tree element used to expand a tree node.
member.remarks: Leave this value as a null value if the regular Select, Expand, or Collapse operations run correctly.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ExtendedTreeViewConfiguration.CollapseXPath
member.summary: The XPath value used to find the internal tree element used to collapse a tree node.
member.remarks: Leave this value as a null value if the regular Select, Expand, or Collapse operations run correctly.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ITreeView.Select(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ITreeViewNode)
member.summary: Selects the specified node in this object.

remarks.para: If the child items in this object are generated dynamically (for example, if they are not visible or present in the application until the parent node is expanded), UFT Developer will not be able to select the items in the tree automatically using this method. Manually add steps to make the nodes visible or expand tree nodes to create the object in the application.

member.param: The to select in the tree.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ITreeView.Select(System.String)
member.summary: Selects the specified node in the tree based on the path to the tree node.

remarks.para: If the child items in this object are generated dynamically (for example, if they are not visible or present in the application until the parent node is expanded), UFT Developer will not be able to select the items in the tree automatically using this method. Manually add steps to make the nodes visible or expand tree nodes to create the object in the application.

member.param: The full path to the tree node to select, separated by semicolons.

member.summary: Collapses this tree node.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IGridBase.FindRowWithCellTextInColumn(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.TextMatch,HP.LFT.SDK.Web.ColumnToSearch)
member.summary: Finds the row with the specified text in the specified column, in cases where the text or columnHeader may appear more than once. Scrolls to the found row if one exists.
member.remarks: Usage example: var row = grid.FindRowWithCellTextInColumn(TextMatch.Match("Portuguese", 2), ColumnToSearch.ByHeader("Language", 1)); This example finds the 3rd occurrence of the text "Portuguese" in the 2nd column with the header "Language".
member.param: Description of the text we are looking for.
The column number or column header in which to search for the text.
member.returns: The requested row if one exists
member.exception: If the requested row cannot be found or error occurs during execution.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Back
member.summary: Navigates to the previous page in the browser history list.
member.remarks: This method is identical to clicking the browser's Back button.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.ClearCache
member.summary: Clears the browser cache.
member.remarks: This method does not clear the browser's cookies. Use to delete the cookies.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Close
member.summary: Closes the browser window (or tab) that this test object represents.
member.remarks: Use the method to close the currently open tab, all sibling tabs, and the parent browser window.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.CloseAllTabs
member.summary: Closes all tabs (if any) and closes the browser window.

remarks.para: Use the method to close only the currently open tab.

Limitation: Your Internet Explorer (IE) browser must be configured to "Always close all tabs". To do this, open two or more tabs in IE. Then close IE. In the message box that pops up, select the "Always close all tabs" option.
Note: This method is not supported on Chrome. Use the Close method instead.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.DeleteCookies
member.summary: Deletes all cookies from the browser.
member.remarks: This method does not clear the browser's cache. Use clear the cache.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.DeleteCookies(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes only cookies that originated from the browser source.
member.param: The full or partial domain of the source. For example, entering MySite.com or MySite.net clears cookies only from the specified site, whereas entering MySite clears cookies from all related domains.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.EmbedScript(System.String)
member.summary: Runs this JavaScript each time a page or frame loads or refreshes in the browser.

remarks.para: - The script remains embedded until you close the browser, or until the run session ends.
- Using this method to perform alert operations may result in unexpected behavior.
- To run this method, the security settings in your Web browser must be set to allow active scripting. Otherwise, steps using this method will fail.

member.param: The full content of the JavaScript to embed.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Forward

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Describe``1(HP.LFT.SDK.IDescription)
member.summary: Describes a child test object.
member.remarks: The current instance test object is the parent of the returned test object. UFT Developer searches for this test object only when an operation on this test object is invoked. This means that if the test object is not found in the application, this command will still succeed. In this case, an exception is thrown only when an operation is invoked.
member.param: The child test object description.
member.returns: The requested child test object with its description.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Describe``1(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.XPathDescription)
member.summary: Describes a child test object using the provided XPath.
member.remarks: The current instance test object is the parent of the returned test object. UFT Developer searches for this test object only when an operation on this test object is invoked. This means that if the test object is not found in the application, this command will still succeed. In this case, an exception is thrown only when an operation is invoked.
member.param: The XPath used to find the child test object.
member.returns: The requested child test object with its description.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IBrowser.Describe``1(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.CSSDescription)
member.summary: Describes a child test object using the provided CSS selector.
member.remarks: The current instance test object is the parent of the returned test object. UFT Developer searches for this test object only when an operation on this test object is invoked. member.param: The CSS selector query used to find the child test object
member.returns: The requested child test object with its description

Generate the encoded value using the Password Encoder utility, available from the UFT Developer > Tools menu in your IDE or from the Windows Start menu.

member.remarks: The current instance test object is the parent of the returned test object. UFT Developer searches for this test object only when an operation on this test object is invoked. member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.WebPinchArgs
member.summary: Arguments that define additional behavior for the Pinch method.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.WebPinchArgs.Scale
member.summary:
The zoom scale resulting from the pinch gesture. This number is the ratio between the distance between the fingers at the end of the pinch gesture to the distance between the fingers at the beginning of the pinch gesture.
For example, if you were to touch a screen with your fingers 6 cm apart, and pinch until your fingers were 3 cm apart, the scale would be 0.5. Likewise, if your fingers were 3 cm apart, and you pinch until your fingers are 6 cm apart, the scale would be 2.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.WebPinchArgs.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the WebPinchArgs class with default arguments (pinches from the center of the object in 1 seconds).
member.param: The zoom scale resulting from the pinch gesture. This number is the ratio between the distance between the fingers at the end of the pinch gesture to the distance between the fingers at the beginning of the pinch gesture. For example, if you were to touch a screen with your fingers 6 cm apart, and pinch until your fingers were 3 cm apart, the scale would be 0.5. Likewise, if your fingers were 3 cm apart, and you pinch until your fingers are 6 cm apart, the scale would be 2.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IWebElement
member.summary: Base interface for Web test objects.
member.remarks: Any <div> tag can be represented as an IWebElement. Any element can be referred to as a WebElement. For example, a button can be searched for as a web element, but not vice versa.

The distance moved on the y-axis.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IWebElement.Pan(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.WebPanArgs)
member.summary: Performs a pan gesture on this object according to the specified behavior.
member.remarks: This method is not supported in Internet Explorer.
member.param: The arguments that define the behavior of the pan operation.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IWebElement.Pinch(System.Double)
member.summary: Performs a pinch gesture of the specified scale on this object.
member.remarks: This method is not supported in Internet Explorer.
member.param:
The zoom scale resulting from the pinch gesture. This is the ratio between the distance between the fingers at the end of the pinch gesture to the distance between the fingers at the beginning of the pinch gesture.
For example, if you were to touch a screen with your fingers 6 cm apart, and pinch until your fingers were 3 cm apart, the scale would be 0.5. Likewise, if your fingers were 3 cm apart, and you pinch until your fingers are 6 cm apart, the scale would be 2.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.IWebElement.Pinch(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.WebPinchArgs)
member.summary: Performs a pinch gesture on this object according to the specified behavior.
member.param: The arguments that define the behavior of the pinch operation.

member.summary: Swipes this object according to the specified behavior.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.BrowserFactory.Attach(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.BrowserDescription)
member.summary: Returns a new instance that is attached to a browser tab that was not opened by UFT Developer (for example, a browser tab that was opened manually or by the AUT).
member.remarks:
is used only when attaching to the browser so transient properties like and can be used.
UFT Developer recognizes browser windows and tabs that it opens (for example, via ). If a browser is opened outside of the UFT Developer context, you need to use the method to acquire the browser tab or window.
Examples: - A browser tab was opened manually while setting up a scenario prior to running a UFT Developer test.
- A test step clicks a link in the AUT that opens a new or replacement browser tab or window.
member.param: for filtering the open tabs.
member.returns: for the launched browser if a single matching browser was found.
member.exception: No open browser tab matches the description.
More than one browser tab matches the description.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Web.BrowserFactory.GetAllOpenBrowsers(HP.LFT.SDK.Web.BrowserDescription)
member.summary: Returns a collection of all open that matches the .
member.remarks: The is used only when attaching to the browser so transient properties like and can be used.
member.param: to filter the opened tabs against. If null, all open browsers will be returned.
member.returns: A collection of objects that are open and match the description.

shape="circle" - x,y,radius
shape="poly" - x1,y1,x2,y2,..,xn,yn

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Utils.ImageUtils.CompareImages(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.Image,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Checks whether two images are a match, given the specified pixel and RGB tolerance values.
member.param: The expected image.
The image to compare to the expected image.
Optional. The percentage of pixels that can differ between the two images, and still be considered a match. Default = 0.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Utils.ImageUtils.CompareImages(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.Image,HP.LFT.SDK.Utils.ImageMaskArea,System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Checks whether the defined mask areas within two images match, given the specified pixel and RGB tolerance values.
member.remarks: Returns true only if the mask areas match and the two provided images are the same size.
member.param: The expected image.
The image to compare to the expected image.
The mask area within the two images to use for the comparison.
Optional. The percentage of pixels that can differ between the two mask areas, and still be considered a match. Default = 0.
Optional. The percent by which the RGB values of the pixels in the two images can differ, and still be considered a match. Default = 0.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.TE.IScreenBase.Sync
M:HP.LFT.SDK.TE.IScreenBase.WaitForText(HP.LFT.SDK.StringProperty,HP.LFT.SDK.TE.Area,System.Int64)
member.summary:
Waits for a specified text to appear on the emulator screen before continuing the run session.
Example 1: This example uses the WaitForText method to wait 10 seconds for the string defined as a regular expression, for example: "CH70001 LAST ACCESS AT 14:27:07 ON THURSDAY":
WaitForText(As.RegExp(@".*LAST ACCESS AT \d\d:\d\d:\d\d ON .*DAY.*"), new Area(3, 1, 3, 80), 10000)
Example 2: This example uses the WaitForText method to wait 5 seconds for a string, for example: "User":
WaitForText("User", new Area(3, 1, 3, 80), 5000)
member.param: The specified for which the emulator screen is waiting. This parameter could be represented as a string or a regular expression.
The where the specified text exists.
The amount of time the emulator screen waits after a response.
member.returns: True if the text was found; otherwise False.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.TE.IScreenBase.WaitForText(HP.LFT.SDK.StringProperty,HP.LFT.SDK.TE.Area)
member.summary:

Example 2: This example uses the WaitForText method to wait 5 seconds for a string, for example: "User":

member.param: The specified for which the emulator screen is waiting. This parameter could be represented as a string or a regular expression.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice
member.summary: An interface that provides low-level keyboard operations.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.PressKey(System.Byte)
member.summary: Presses the specified key using a keyboard scan code.
member.remarks: Supports scan code set 1, such as the list shown at: http://www.computer-engineering.org/ps2keyboard/scancodes1.html
member.param: The keyboard scan code of the key.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.PressKey(HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard.Keys)
member.summary: Presses the specified key using a keyboard virtual key.
member.param: The keyboard code of the key.Possible values:

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.KeyDown(System.Byte)
member.summary: Presses and holds the specified key using a keyboard scan code.
member.remarks: Supports scan code set 1, such as the list shown at: http://www.computer-engineering.org/ps2keyboard/scancodes1.html
member.param: The keyboard scan code of the key to hold.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.KeyDown(HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard.Keys)
member.summary: Presses and holds the specified key using a keyboard virtual key.
member.param: The keyboard code of the key to hold. Possible values:

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.KeyUp(System.Byte)
member.summary: Releases the specified key based on its keyboard scan code.
member.remarks: Supports scan code set 1, such as the list shown at: http://www.computer-engineering.org/ps2keyboard/scancodes1.html
member.param: The keyboard scan code of the key to release.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.KeyUp(HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard.Keys)
member.summary: Releases the specified key based on its keyboard virtual key.
member.param: The keyboard code of the key to release.Possible values:

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IKeyboardDevice.SendString(System.String)
member.summary: Types the specified string.
member.param: The string to type.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice
member.summary: An interface that provides low-level mouse operations.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.Click(System.Drawing.Point,HP.LFT.SDK.MouseButton)
member.summary: Moves the mouse to the specified point on the screen and clicks the specified mouse button.
member.param: The on the screen to place the mouse pointer.
Optional. The mouse button that performs the click. Possible Values: . Default = MouseButton.Left.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.DoubleClick(System.Drawing.Point,HP.LFT.SDK.MouseButton)
member.summary: Moves the mouse to the specified point on the screen and double-clicks the specified mouse button.
member.param: The on the screen to place the mouse pointer.
Optional. The mouse button that performs the double-click. Possible Values: . Default = MouseButton.Left.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.DragAndDrop(System.Drawing.Point,System.Drawing.Point,HP.LFT.SDK.MouseButton)
member.summary: Drags the mouse from and to the specified points while the specified mouse button is pressed, and then releases the mouse button.
member.param: The from which to perform the drag and drop operation.
The where the drag ends and the mouse button is released.
Optional. The mouse button that is pressed during the drag operation. Possible Values: . Default = MouseButton.Left.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.ButtonDown(System.Drawing.Point,HP.LFT.SDK.MouseButton)
member.summary: Presses the specified mouse button at the specified point on the screen.
member.param: The where the mouse button is pressed.
Optional. The mouse button to press. Possible Values: . Default = MouseButton.Left.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.ButtonUp(System.Drawing.Point,HP.LFT.SDK.MouseButton)
member.summary: Releases the specified mouse button at the specified point on the screen.
member.param: The where the mouse button is released.
Optional. The mouse button to release. Possible Values: . Default = MouseButton.Left.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.IMouseDevice.Move(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Moves the mouse to the specified point on the screen.
member.param: The on the screen to place the mouse pointer.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard
member.summary: A class that enables low-level keyboard device operations. When working in a grid configuration, use in order to get the object, which enables keyboard operations on a specific environment or grid node.

member.param: The keyboard scan code of the key.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard.PressKey(HP.LFT.SDK.Keyboard.Keys)
member.summary: Presses the specified key using a keyboard virtual key.

member.summary: A .NET WPF calendar or a date picker object.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.ICalendar.HelpText
member.summary: The help text associated with this object.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.ICalendar.ParentText
member.summary: The text associated with the parent object of this object.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.ICalendar.Date
member.summary: Either the date or the start date of the date range associated with this object. Note:
member.remarks:
- In case a date range is selected, the Date property will return the start date of the range.
- If you try to retrieve a date value from a WPFcalendar object (e.g. calendar.Date; calendar.Date.Month; calendar.Date.Year)before performing an operation on it, UFT Developer returns an exception of type:InvalidOperationException. Therefore, make sure to precede the retrieve value step with a step that performs an operation on the calendar, such as using to set the date on the calendar to the current date.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.ICalendar.DateRanges
member.summary: The selected date range of this Month Calendar control in multi-selection mode.
member.remarks:
If a single date is selected in the calendar:
DateRanges returns an array with a single element.
Both DateRange.StartDate and DateRange.EndDate are equal to the selected date.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.IEditField.SetSecure(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the encoded value of this edit box.
member.remarks:
Generate the encoded value using the Password Encoder utility, available from the UFT Developer > Tools menu in your IDE or from the Windows Start menu.
Note: The SetSecure method enables you to hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, but it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.
member.param: The encoded text to enter in this edit box.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.IMenu.Select(System.String)
member.summary: Selects the specified item.
member.param:
The path of the item.
Tip: You can use the BuildMenuPath method to build the item path string that can then be used as the itemPath argument for this method.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.WPF.IMenu.GetItem(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the menu item with the specified path.
member.param:
The full path of the menu item to select from the list. The path is composed of the menu item names or a numeric index separated by a semicolon.
To specify the index of the item to select, use <Item n>. Index values begin with 1.
For example, File;<Item 3gt;;Move;<Item gt;...

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Insight.IInsightObject.SetSecure(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the encoded value of this editable field object.
member.remarks:
Generate the encoded value using the Password Encoder utility, available from the UFT Developer > Tools menu in your IDE or from the Windows Start menu.
Note: The SetSecure method enables you to hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, but it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.
member.param: The encoded text to enter in this edit box.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Location
member.summary: Provides a location (relative to an object in the application) for operations that support it. For example, the Click method uses the Location structure to determine where inside this object to perform the click.

member.summary: The object position from which the offset is taken. Possible values: .

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Location.Offset
member.summary: The x- and y- offset (in pixels) from the anchor position. Default value = 0,0.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Location.#ctor(HP.LFT.SDK.Position,System.Nullable{System.Drawing.Point})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance the using the specified object position and offset points.
member.param: The object position from which the offset is taken. Possible values: .
The x- and y- offset (in pixels) from the anchor position. If null, the point is (0,0).

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.Description
member.summary: The base class for all Description classes that support the index and Visual Relation Identifier (VRI) test object properties.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Description.Index
member.summary: The 0-based index of this object, relative to all other objects with an otherwise identical description.

members.member:
QUESTION - Niv/Avishay: What are the possible values? Should they be exposed?
The type of index. Default is Index.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.Description.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an empty description.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.Description.Vri
member.summary: Distinguishes this object from other objects with otherwise identical descriptions, based on this object's visual relationship to another object in the application.
member.remarks: For example if you have 10 identical buttons with the text label "Buy" and no other real property to distinguish between them, you can use VRI to indicate that this test object represents the "Buy" button that is located to the right of the image of a specific product. The Vri property value is a object that defines the test object you are relating to, and where that related object is located on the screen relative to the object to identify. For more details, see the UFT Developer Help Center.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation
member.summary: Class representing Visual Relations Identifier (VRI) data. Each VisualRelation class contains a reference to a test object, and up to three possible relations: horizontal relation, vertical relation, and proximity relation.
member.remarks: See the UFT Developer Help Center for more information on VRI, including a diagram that illustrates the way UFT Developer interprets visual relations and the boundaries that are used for determining in-line related objects.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with null values for all 3 relation elements.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.TestObject
member.summary: The related test object.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.HorizontalRelation
member.summary: The horizontal relation definition.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.VerticalRelation
member.summary: The vertical relation defintion.

member.name: P:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.ProximityRelation
member.summary: The proximity relation definition.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.VisualRelation.Clone
member.summary: Creates an exact copy of this object.
member.returns: a deep copy of the instance.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.HorizontalVisualRelation
member.summary: The horizontal location of the related test object relative to the object to identify. See the UFT Developer Help Center for a diagram that illustrates the way UFT Developer interprets visual relations and the boundaries that are used for determining in-line related objects.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.HorizontalVisualRelation.Left
member.summary: The related test object is located to the left of the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.HorizontalVisualRelation.LeftAndInline
member.summary: The related test object is located to the left of the test object to identify and is horizontally inline with it.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.HorizontalVisualRelation.Right
member.summary: The related test object is located to the right of the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.HorizontalVisualRelation.RightAndInline
member.summary: The related test object is locatedto the right of the test object to identify and is horizontally inline with it.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.VerticalVisualRelation
member.summary: The vertical location of the related test object relative to the object to identify. See the UFT Developer Help Center for a diagram that illustrates the way UFT Developer interprets visual relations and the boundaries that are used for determining in-line related objects.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.VerticalVisualRelation.Above
member.summary: The related test object is located above the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.VerticalVisualRelation.AboveAndInline
member.summary: The related test object is located above the test object to identify and vertically inline with it.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.VerticalVisualRelation.Below
member.summary: The related test object is located below the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.VerticalVisualRelation.BelowAndInline
member.summary: The related test object is located below the test object to identify and vertically inline with it.

member.name: T:HP.LFT.SDK.ProximityVisualRelation
member.summary: The distance or hierarchical location of the related test object relative to the object to identify. See the UFT Developer Help Center for more details on VRI.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.ProximityVisualRelation.ClosestOnXAxis
member.summary: The related test object is the closest object on the x-axis to the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.ProximityVisualRelation.ClosestOnYAxis
member.summary: The related test object is the closest object on the y-axis to the test object to identify.

member.name: F:HP.LFT.SDK.ProximityVisualRelation.ClosestOnBothAxes
member.summary: The related test object is the closest object on both the x- and y- axes to the test object to identify.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.StdWin.IEditField.SetSecure(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the encoded value of this edit box.
member.remarks:
Generate the encoded value using the Password Encoder utility, available from the UFT Developer > Tools menu in your IDE or from the Windows Start menu.
Note: The SetSecure method enables you to hide passwords displayed on the screen while running or editing a UFT Developer test, but it is not intended to be a secure way to protect password information.
member.param: The encoded text to enter in this edit box.

member.name: M:HP.LFT.SDK.StdWin.IMenu.GetItem(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the menu item with the specified path. Tip: To check whether the item exists, use the MenuItem.Exists property.
member.param: The full path of the menu item to return. The path is composed of the menu item names or a numeric index separated by a semicolon. To specify the index of the item to select, use <Item #>. Index values begin with 1. Tip: Use the BuildMenuPath method to build the item path string to be used as the itemPath argument for this method.
member.returns: The menu item (IMenuItem) found at the specified item path
